children.label: economic sustainability
children.definition: The application of economic concepts, models, and tools to the sustainable development of resources, businesses and communities.

children.label: life cycle costing
children.definition: The life cycle cost of a product or project includes discounted costs of operation, maintenance, contracting, and disposal/decommissioning in addition to initial acquisition cost.

children.label: environmentally preferable purchasing
children.definition: Buying of renewable, environmentally-friendly or biobased products to provide benefits including climate change impact reduction, energy security and sustainable economic development.

children.label: ecolabeling
children.definition: A symbol, graphic or statement that appears on products or their packaging in order to convey an environmental aspect of that product to the consumer.

children.label: environmental product declaration
children.definition: A standardized (ISO 14025/TR) life-cycle assessment-based mechanism to communicate quantified life-cycle environmental information for a product.

children.label: product category rule
children.definition: A product category rule is a set of detailed rules, requirements, and guidelines for developing environmental declarations for a class of products. PCRs set the methods and life-cycle assessment boundary conditions that underpin an environmental product declaration.

children.label: ecological economics
children.definition: A transdisciplinary field of study that integrates environmental, social and economic systems that examines the economic values of non-market products and services where the economy is connected to, and sustained by, a flow of energy and materials in the natural environment.

children.label: eco-efficiency
children.definition: The relationship between economic outputs of products, processes and services and their environmental impact, with the goal being efficient use of materials and energy throughout the life cycle in order to reduce economic and ecological costs.

children.label: ecosystem services
children.definition: Benefits people and other organisms obtain from ecosystems; examples include: pure water and clean air, scenic landscapes, wildlife habitat and biodiversity.

children.label: National Center for the Replacement, Refinement and Reduction of Animals in Research
children.definition: The NC3Rs is a UK-based scientific organisation dedicated to replacing, refining and reducing the use of animals in research and testing (the 3Rs).

children.label: labor unions
children.definition: Association of workers formed for the purpose of collective bargaining with employers for the benefit of the workers, such as wages, working conditions, etc.

children.label: Center for Alternatives to Animal Testing
children.definition: CAAT promote humane science by supporting the creation, development, validation, and use of alternatives to animals in research, product safety testing, and education.

children.label: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee
agricultural experiment stations
children.definition: Centers where scientific research is conducted in order to improve food and agricultural production. Experiment station scientists and staff work with farmers and other members of the agriculture and food industry.

children.label: water users associations
children.definition: An organization whose members pool resources in a cooperative effort to manage, operate, monitor and maintain a water source or irrigation system.

children.label: National Center for the Replacement Refinement and Reduction of Animals in Research
Fund for the Replacement of Animals in Medical Experiments
Future Farmers of America
children.definition: An organization for high school students studying vocational agriculture.

children.label: Research and Education Center for Tropical Agriculture
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee
Inter-American Institute for Cooperation on Agriculture
International Organization for Standardization
children.definition: Worldwide organization consisting of a network of the national standards institutes of countries formed to promote development of standards to facilitate the international carriage and exchange of goods and service and to develop mutual cooperation in the spheres of intellectual, scientific, technological, and economic activities.

children.label: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
The Nature Conservancy
children.definition: An international conservation organization that purchases lands in order to preserve plants, animals and natural communities.

children.label: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
United Nations Environment Programme
children.definition: International environmental program administered by the United Nations whose mission is to lead countries in efforts to care for the environment.

children.label: World Organization for Animal Health
children.definition: The World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) is the intergovernmental organisation responsible for improving animal health worldwide and fighting animal diseases at a global level.

children.label: Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care International
children.definition: AAALAC International is a private, nonprofit organization that promotes the humane treatment of animals in science through voluntary accreditation and assessment programs.

children.label: International Union of Forest Research Organization
Animal Welfare Institute
children.definition: The Animal Welfare Institute is an American, non-profit, charitable organization founded in 1951 with the goal of reducing pain and fear inflicted on animals by humans. Its legislative division, the Society for Animal Protective Legislation, pushes for the passage of laws that reflect this purpose.

children.label: American Society for Cellular and Computational Toxicology
children.definition: The American Society for Cellular and Computational Toxicology (ASCCT) is a scientific society dedicated to the promotion of toxicology testing and research that reduces and replaces the use of animals.

children.label: American Association for Laboratory Animal Science
children.definition: American Association for Laboratory Animal Science (AALAS) is an association of professionals that advances responsible laboratory animal care and use to benefit people and animals.

children.label: Interagency Coordinating Committee on the Validation of Alternative Methods
trade associations
children.definition: An organization comprised of businesses, manufacturers and individuals who are in the same trade or industry and have organized in order to promote common interests, such as promotion of an industry or adoption of standards within an industry.

children.label: persuasion
children.definition: A mode of communication concerned with inducing or urging the adoption of certain beliefs, theories, or lines of action by others.

children.label: statistical appeal
children.definition: Persuasive tactic which uses statistical evidence to communicate a message, usually evoking a cognitive response.

children.label: narrative appeal
children.definition: Persuasive tactic which uses descriptive evidence in the form of stories to communicate a message, usually evoking an emotional response.

children.label: message mapping
children.definition: A model that hierarchically organizes an organization's messages regarding controversial issues.

children.label: socioeconomic status
children.definition: A stratum of people with similar position and prestige; includes social stratification. Social class is measured by criteria such as education, occupation, and income.

children.label: social mobility
children.definition: The upward or downward movement of individuals or groups into different positions in a social hierarchy based on wealth, income, occupation, education, social power, or any other scarce social resources. A society with a high rate of social mobility and good opportunities for upward social mobility is not egalitarian but does maximize opportunities for one individual or group to get more of the society's scarce resources than other individuals or groups can get.

children.label: social inequality
children.definition: A condition in which various members of a society have unequal amounts of income, prestige, and social power.

children.label: demographic statistics
children.definition: Concept limited to the population statistics of any population.

children.label: social sustainability
children.definition: The component of sustainability that includes human rights, labor rights, and national, international and corporate governance.

children.label: cooking instruction
children.definition: An educational method utilized to demonstrate food preparation techniques.

children.label: extension programs
children.definition: Structured programs (such as the Master Gardener Program, Pesticide Certification Program, etc.) with a target audience and defined curricula which is conducted within a specific period of time.

children.label: parenthood education
children.definition: An organized program that teaches children or teenagers about child care and development, and the role of parents. It provides information, knowledge, awareness and skills for effective parenthood.

children.label: continuing education
children.definition: Educational programs designed to inform individuals of recent advances in their particular field of interest. They do not lead to any formal advanced standing.

children.label: early childhood education
children.definition: Education of students from preschool through grade 3.

children.label: kindergarten
children.definition: The first year of formal education for children usually between 4 and 6 years of age, preparing them for first grade in elementary school.

children.label: Head Start
children.definition: A federal program that promotes the school readiness of children ages birth to 5 from low-income families by enhancing their cognitive, social and emotional development.

children.label: special education
children.definition: Education programs for students who need specialized teaching methods or materials because they have different intellectual, physical, emotional or social characteristics than the normal student.

children.label: teacher education
children.definition: Education or training of teachers.

children.label: child development centers
children.definition: Educational facilities for preschool children, which also provide health and family services- originally used in connection with Project Head Start for centers in which cooperation of family, community, and professional staff contribute to the total development of the child.

children.label: veterinary schools
children.definition: Educational institutions for individuals specializing in the field of veterinary medicine.

children.label: preschools
children.definition: Schools for preschool children, usually 2 1/2 to 5 1/2 years of age-- nursery school programs are either part-day or part-week and may be operated as a service by public schools, or for profit by other agencies or individuals.

children.label: small schools
children.definition: Although the designation of "small" is relative to locale, small schools of grades K-12 usually do not exceed 750 students.

children.label: agricultural colleges
children.definition: Educational institutions offering a curriculum in agricultural sciences.

children.label: tribal colleges
children.definition: Post-secondary educational institutions on tribal lands in the United States; Native American colleges given land grant status by an Act of Congress in 1994 are known as the 1994 Institutions.

children.label: elementary education
children.definition: Education of students from kindergarten through grades 6, 7, or 8 (which is dependent on the school system).

children.label: distance education
children.definition: Education delivery via one or more communications media (e.g., correspondence, radio, television, video, computer) with little or no classroom or other face-to-face contact between teachers and students.

children.label: online courses
children.definition: Educational lessons delivered via the Internet to students. Students and instructor may not meet face to face but interact through web-based software and email.

children.label: vocational education
children.definition: Education for specific trades or occupations.

children.label: educational status
children.definition: Educational attainment or level of education of individuals.

children.label: academic achievement
children.definition: Accomplishments relating to education, learning and study, especially in schools and higher educational institutions.

children.label: certification (education)
children.definition: Receipt of documentation of the completion of a course of study which does not lead to a diploma.

children.label: literacy
children.definition: Ability to read and write.

children.label: adult literacy
children.definition: The ability of adults (ages 18 and older) to read and write.

children.label: computer literacy
children.definition: Having the basic skills in the use of computers.

children.label: secondary education
children.definition: Education of students from grade 7, 8, or 9 through grade 12 (which is dependent on the school system).

children.label: environmental education
children.definition: Educational programs and training about environmental issues, environmental protection and environmental management.

children.label: Muslims
children.definition: People who practice the religion of Islam.

children.label: design
children.definition: The component of the planning process which controls the actual physical changes that will occur in time and space. At higher levels of planning, the design component sets the general guidelines for the spatial pattern and physical character of development. At the individual project level design is the activity which sets the precise character, pattern and form of the project environment.

children.label: historic preservation
children.definition: The identification, rehabilitation, maintenance and protection of historically important architecture, buildings, sites, landmarks, landscapes or other cultural objects.

children.label: historic sites
children.definition: Any area, site, structure or landmark that has special significance to the history, pre-history, architecture or culture of a region, locality, community or nation.

children.label: aesthetics
children.definition: Pertaining to the quality of human perceptual experience (including sight, sound, smell, touch, taste, and movement) evoked by phenomena or elements or configurations of elements in the environment.

children.label: metaphysics
children.definition: The branch of philosophy that treats of first principles, including ontology (the nature of existence or being) and cosmology (the origin and structure of the universe).

children.label: social justice
children.definition: An interactive process whereby members of a community are concerned for the equality and rights of all.

children.label: bioethics
children.definition: A branch of applied ethics that studies the value implications of practices and developments in life sciences, medicine, and health care.

children.label: whistleblowing
children.definition: The reporting of observed or suspected professional misconduct or incompetence to appropriate authorities or to the public.

children.label: acculturation
children.definition: The processes and results of contact between two or more different cultures. Generally, acculturation brings about considerable diffusion of cultural traits in one or more directions. However, other change-processes also occur, such as development of new intercultural roles, the growth of new customs not found in either culture and the disintegration of older cultural forms.

children.label: people with disabilities
children.definition: People who have a disability or impairment of any type that interferes with their daily usual activities and are unable to perform certain functions as most others. They may need some special accomodations.

children.label: allied health professionals
children.definition: Health care workers specially trained and licensed to assist and support the work of health professionals. Often used synonymously with paramedical personnel, the term generally refers to all health care workers who perform tasks which must otherwise be performed by a physician or other health professional.

children.label: diabetes educators
children.definition: A health care professional who teaches people who have diabetes how to manage their diabetes.

children.label: risk communicators
children.definition: Persons who perform risk communication.

children.label: Pacific Islanders
children.definition: People who identify themselves as having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands.

children.label: indigenous peoples
children.definition: People native to a particular area.

children.label: First Nations
children.definition: The aboriginal groups formally recognized by the Canadian government under the federal Indian Act of 1876.

children.label: American Indians
children.definition: Peoples indigenous to North, Central and South Americas, except Alaska.

children.label: Navajo Indians
children.definition: Peoples indigenous to Southwestern United States. It is the largest tribe of all Native American Indians.

children.label: Blacks
children.definition: People who identify themselves as having origins in any of the black racial groups of Africa.

children.label: Asians
children.definition: People identify themselves as having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the India subcontinent.

children.label: Arabs
children.definition: People who identify their nationality, ethnic identity, ancestry or first language as Arabic.

children.label: Latinos
children.definition: People who identify their nationality, ethnic identity, or ancestry as Latin American

children.label: Whites
children.definition: People who identify themselves as having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, North Africa, or the Middle East.

children.label: Jews
children.definition: People who practice Judaism and/or identify their ethnic identity or ancestry as Jewish.

children.label: refugees
children.definition: Persons fleeing to a place of safety, especially those who flee to a foreign country or power to escape danger or persecution in their own country or habitual residence because of race, religion, or political belief.

children.label: farmers
children.definition: A person who is engaged in the raising of crops, poultry or livestock.

children.label: ranchers
children.definition: People who raise livestock on rangeland.

children.label: stakeholders
children.definition: Individuals, groups or organizations that have an interest in or are affected by the activities of government, business or other organization.

children.label: horticulturists
children.definition: Persons educated in the science and art of cultivating fruits, vegetables and ornamental plants.

children.label: minority students
children.definition: Students who are members of minority groups.

children.label: students with disabilities
children.definition: Students who have a disability or impairment of any type that interferes with their daily usual activities and are unable to perform certain functions as most others. They may need some special accomodations.

children.label: farm operators
children.definition: An individual or group that controls the day-to-day management and decision-making of a farming operation.

children.label: hunters
children.definition: A person who hunts wild animals for food or their parts (skin, hairs, feathers, bones etc.) or in sport.

children.label: risk assessors
children.definition: Persons who perform risk assessment.

children.label: people with special needs
children.definition: People who are identified as needing special assistance, special physical environment, special training, special technology, or etc. which is beyond what is typically required by most of the population. People with special needs may include the disabled, financially disadvantaged, limited English-speakers, people with emotional problems, or homeless people.

children.label: toddlers
children.definition: Young children who are just learning to walk.

children.label: veterans
children.definition: Any person with extended experience in a particular occupation or activity.

children.label: gardeners
children.definition: Persons who tend a garden.

children.label: extension agents
children.definition: An educator employed by a county and/or a State cooperative extension service to bring research-based agriculture and quality of life education to local people to help them address farm, home, and community problems at the local level.

children.label: life history
children.definition: A continuous, descriptive account of the life cycle of an organism.

children.label: recreation
children.definition: Leisure time activity such as swimming, picnicking, boating, hunting and fishing.

children.label: recreation areas
children.definition: A relatively small, distinctly defined area where concentrated public use for the more traditional recreation purposes predominates - e.g., campgrounds, picnic areas, swimming areas.

children.label: tourism
children.definition: The industry that provides local entertainment, accommodation, transportation, catering and other services to visitors and travelers.

children.label: agritourism
children.definition: A form of commercial enterprise that links agricultural production and/or processing with tourism in order to attract visitors onto a farm, ranch, or other agricultural business for the purposes of entertaining and/or educating the visitors and generating income for the farm, ranch, or business owner.

children.label: ecotourism
children.definition: Travel to natural settings with focus on the appreciation, conservation, preservation and sustainability of the area's natural resources and its surrounding community.
